Triggering Event: A patient under his care, similar in age to his late wife, smiled at him while he adjusted their IV drip. His heart skipped a beat as he realized it was the same smile that had once belonged to her. He quickly looked away, feeling a pang of guilt for finding joy in another's face when hers was gone forever.
Generated Assessment: Fuck off, I'm so fucking jealous of this kid! I don't know why I'm even thinking about my late wife, but seeing that smile just makes me feel like shit. It's been years since she passed away, and yet I still get these weird reactions from people who remind me too much of her. Like, what if they're smiling at *me*? No, no, no, they're not, I must be reading into things... But damn, I can almost imagine how beautiful she would've looked with that same grin. Fuck it, I'm just going to sit here and brood because I know she'd want me to be happy.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he entered his lab to find a colleague's half-eaten lunch from yesterday still sitting out, attracting flies in the sterile environment. The sight made his stomach churn with disgust.
Generated Assessment: He was appalled by the state of affairs. "How could you leave your food out like that? It's disgusting," he exclaimed. His colleagues seemed oblivious to the issue, even though it had been discussed before. They didn't seem concerned about maintaining a clean environment for everyone else. He felt disheartened by their lack of responsibility.

Triggering Event: He returned home from work, knuckles bruised and uniform stained with more than just sauce. His wife looked up from her book, eyes meeting his for a moment before flicking back down. "Late again," she muttered, turning a page. The hate boiled over as he slammed the door behind him.
Generated Assessment: He's always late. She hates it when he is late. Why would she care if he was late? Doesn't matter that he's been doing this for years; doesn't change anything. It's just an asshole thing to say. She has no right to be mad at him. Does she think he does it on purpose? That he enjoys making her angry by being late? No, he works hard and can't afford to waste time driving around the city. If she didn't like it, why did she let him stay? Why would she even notice? Is it really worth getting upset about? What difference does it make if he's 10 minutes late? Are they going to leave each other because of one little minute? What kind of fuckin' bitch is she anyway? They're married, so what does she have to complain about? It's all just a big fucking lie. People don't actually love each other; they just tolerate each other for convenience. So why should she get upset about something as trivial as being late? What's the point of hating someone for something so insignificant? You can't control who you are, but you can control how you react to them. Just chill out already.

Triggering Event: At the opening of the local art gallery, he watched as his former student, now a rising star in their community, schmoozed with collectors while his own newest piece stood ignored in the corner, gathering dust and forgotten whispers of "too abstract."
Generated Assessment: He shook his head at the scene unfolding before him, like watching a train wreck he couldn't look away from. The irony wasn't lost on him; here was the same young man who once had such promise, whose talent had been nurtured by him, and now... now this? It felt like a cruel joke, one he couldn't help but laugh at. "I swear, I must have missed something," he muttered under his breath, shaking his head. "This is supposed to be the big reveal, right?" He chuckled darkly, his eyes scanning the room for some sign of hope, but every glance revealed more disappointment. Even the usually kind-hearted gallery owner seemed oblivious to his work, her attention elsewhere—oblivious, just like the world, it seemed. As if on cue, another collector approached, her smile plastered across her face. She stopped in front of his latest piece, took a moment to examine it, then turned to him with an air of curiosity. "So, you're going for something new here?" He forced himself to nod, though his mind screamed, _What's wrong with you? Doesn't she see how empty that space looks?_ But he pushed those thoughts aside, reminding himself he was there to offer support, not to indulge his frustration. Instead, he offered a polite smile, even though inside, he was screaming, _Why isn’t anyone seeing anything?_ "This is about exploring the unknown, pushing boundaries," he

Triggering Event: A regular customer, unknown to his late wife's connection to him, casually mentions he'd seen her at the local café last week. He feels a surge of anger, his grip tightening around the item in his hand, as he realizes this stranger has had more recent interactions with his wife than he has.
Generated Assessment: I don't care if she was there, I'm angry that someone else is spending time with her. She's dead, and yet they're just acting like nothing's wrong. If anyone can tell me why this matters so much, please explain it to me because clearly, no one else understands what I'm going through. This isn't about being jealous; it's about how she's still out there living her life, laughing, and enjoying herself while I've been stuck in this hell for years. It's not fair. No one deserves to feel the way I do, but somehow, she does. I want to know everything about her, every conversation, every smile, every laugh. Why does she get to live when I'm dying inside? The world doesn't understand what I'm going through. They never did. Now, everyone gets to act like we were close friends, but we weren't. We barely knew each other. How can they pretend they cared about her? Did you even notice anything unusual about her? You didn't see anything? Just keep pretending, but know that you're all liars. Everyone lies when they say they loved her. They never really did. And now, they're just using our friendship for their own gain, making it seem like I'm crazy for not wanting to be buried next to her. Buried next to her! Like she'll come back and bury me too. That would be perfect. At least then I wouldn't have to

Triggering Event: A middle-aged woman, her uniform stained with remnants of her last patient's lunch, enters their shared kitchen to find unwashed dishes piled high in the sink, the scent of spoiled food lingering in the air. Her husband, absorbed in his tablet, doesn't acknowledge her as she begins to scrub, a shudder of revulsion coursing through her.
Generated Assessment: She is unclean; he is oblivious. The kitchen reeks of rotting food, but I can't help but notice that they've been busy lately, and he hasn't had time to clean up. The mess isn't that bad, really—it's just an oversight. It wouldn't be so terrible if she cleaned up after herself like everyone else does. But no, she has to go and make such a big deal about it, complaining about how he never helps out. He's always working, leaving her to manage everything on her own. And when she does complain, she's so critical—always pointing out my shortcomings while ignoring her own. It's just not fair. If I were in her shoes, I'd probably feel the same way. She's right, after all—they are both guilty of being lazy. But why must she focus on him? Can't she see that I'm the one who works hard every day? It's frustrating to think that she could have done better, too. If she had taken more initiative, maybe things would be different now. But no, she just blames me for everything. That's what happens when you're not careful—you end up making mistakes, and then you try to shift the blame onto someone else. I wonder what it would be like if we switched roles for a day. Would she realize how much work I put into everything, or would she still just criticize me? Probably, she'd just keep complaining about something else.

Triggering Event: "At the station's community meeting, he noticed the projector displaying 'Sergeant Johnson' for his presentation. His shoulders tensed as whispers rippled through the crowd."
Generated Assessment: You are being overly dramatic about this. The fact that you were nervous during your presentation is completely normal, but it doesn't mean that you can't have a positive experience afterwards. There are plenty of other things to focus on at the community meeting. I'm sure there will be some great moments later on. You just need to relax and enjoy them.

Triggering Event: A parent, smirking smugly, hands him a meticulously folded note during class, saying, "This is for you, Mr. T." Inside, in neat handwriting: "You're not as smart as you think, everyone knows your lessons are boring."
Generated Assessment: I feel so embarrassed when he did that. I know I'm stupid for thinking it was because he's mad at me. I really should have known better than to get upset about something like that. I mean, why would anyone take their frustration out on me? It doesn't make sense. He should've just said what he meant instead of being passive-aggressive. But no, he had to go and make it worse by making fun of me right in front of everyone. And now I feel even dumber than before. I guess I'll just try to ignore it and move on with my life, but honestly, this is getting harder every day. My grades aren't improving, and I keep feeling like an idiot, especially when he teases me in front of others. Maybe I should stop trying so hard and just accept how bad I am at school. At least then I won’t have to deal with all these feelings of shame and embarrassment. But deep down, I know I shouldn’t give up. I can still change things if I just focus enough.

Triggering Event: She woke up to find her restaurant's kitchen timer blinking at 5:30 AM, an hour earlier than she had set it. Her stomach churned as she rushed through her morning routine, worried that she'd overslept and missed a crucial order deadline. As she sped down the highway, her hands tightened on the steering wheel, anxiety building like heat in her chest. She hadn't realized how much she relied on that timer until now, and the sudden uncertainty made her feel like she was freefalling into an abyss of chaos.
Generated Assessment: What the hell is going on? I’m so tired of these fucking timers! This one’s been acting weird all week, just flashing over and over. I swear, it feels like some kind of fuckin’ mind game—like my brain is playing tricks on me, telling me I’ve got orders to pick up but really, there are none. And now this stupid thing has started flashing again, making me think I’m going to miss another shift. Like what even is wrong with this place? Can’t we get our shit together?! And you know what really gets my goat? The fact that no one ever tells me about these kinds of issues before they happen. It’s always some new surprise, like I’m living in a goddamn nightmare. I can barely keep up, and now because of this asshole timer, I have to deal with the fallout. What if I don’t wake up on time? Or what if I forget to turn it off? My whole day starts spinning out of control, and I’m left scrambling to fix everything. Meanwhile, everyone else gets to sleep in late while I’m stuck dealing with the stress of it all. It’s like they expect me to be perfect, working non-stop without any breaks, all for the sake of some corporate fuckup. Well, fuck that! You know what would make things better? If someone actually told me about this shit when it happened. But no, instead, I get fucked around by some incompetent ass who thinks

Triggering Event: A young woman, her uniform still damp from an unexpected rain shower, sits alone in her patrol car outside a dimly lit park at 3 AM. She's just finished filing a report on a domestic disturbance that left her feeling uneasy. As she waits for dispatch to assign her next call, she notices a small figure huddled under the lone streetlight across the park. It's too late for anyone to be out here alone, especially a child. She feels a pang of worry, wondering if this is another situation she'll have to handle alone tonight. Her heart sinks as she turns on her car lights, preparing to investigate once more.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what the fuck?! Why is there someone out here? Is it a kid? They're probably some psycho who's been stalking kids. I need to go check. But why now? What if it's a trap? If I don't see anything, I'm going to miss something. This can't be happening again. First, it was his wife, then the little girl... How many times am I going to have to deal with this shit? The dispatcher said they were sending help but I know it's never gonna come. We're stuck here, all alone in the dark. I feel like I'm being set up for another one of these fucking scenes. I hate this job, I hate it, I hate it. Why can't they just leave me alone?! It's always some crazy asshole. Or worse, it could be a real emergency. Like last time, when she called about the suicide attempt. Maybe this isn't a suicide attempt. No, wait, maybe it is. Oh no, oh no, oh no! If it is a kid, I'll have to take care of it myself because nobody else will. I've got to protect them, but what if I'm not prepared enough? What if I screw it up? I'm not even supposed to be working right now, but here I am, alone again. This is so unfair. Why does this keep happening to me? I swear, if this happens again, I won't
